Another epic Pack! Thanks for ALL of it.

[+1] Thanks for this pack.
I have a question:
I've read that it is more desirable to encode in resolutions that are either one- half, third, or quarter of the resolution of your display device. Reasoning is, pixels that have to be multiplied by non-whole numbers sometimes are skewed/distorted. I haven't noticed it personally, but are you aware of this anomaly? For instance, I have a 1920x1080p plasma, so if I wanted to maintain small size while only doubling pixels on display I'd do 960x540... Thoughts?

@jmac85: There is no simple answer to that. End-user and his playback system always has some restrictions. Other side (encoding mechanism) has restrictions too, like preferred frame size should be dividable with 16. H264/x264/AVC even asks for that and is defined as part of h264 standard. 

H264 compressors are able to use and determine (hard-code within) a pixel aspect ratio and manipulate display size, unlike decade old XviD/DivX which possessed some rudimentary ways of those, but never was fully developed.

So, when you encode, you automatically obey the rules of specific codec and specific target - in case of H264,  one must stay "in" corresponding H264 built-in profile/level.

For SAR and PAR 1:1 (when you encode) any frame-size (W and H) should be dividable with 16 - just care about division with 16 or 32 and you would be fine.

Number of pixels (W multiplied with H) must be in accordance with target-profile.

Aspect-ratio would be derived from PAR and SAR, keeping in mind that if one pixel is 1x1 (PAR and SAR) and  frame size is 400x300, one can hard-code DAR (display aspect ratio) as 1.2 and NOT 1.33 as he mathematically is, also when pixel has hard-coded aspect ratio of 0.97 - display aspect ratio is different.

Majority of people have no idea about that, and that's why I find all morons who have something to say about - incredibly silly.

I suggest you to hard-code PAR (SAR) as 1:1 and follow modern standards for resolutions. IF (very often) aspect ratio should be corrected (I do that as a rule), simple corrections of output frame sizes in 16 or 32 steps are best and safest way to go.

Beside, all, especially HD resolutions, are well known and you have good wikipedia page for that, with links to other pages about the same subject.
